title: How is the site WhiteHat Jr. for teaching coding for children? - Quora

response.answer_text: Luckily i had a bad experience with whitehat jr. And ended up in a much better way.. So i called whitehat jr and organised a free lesson for my son to see how it goes When the lesson started the instructor was not really teachin my son, rather she was only kind of ordering him what to do without giving him the chance to think or even make mistakes by himself to learn or conclude things, Nevertheless we agreed to go on with the classes and i requested that they call me next day in the afternoon so we can do the registration coz i got busy. They agreed, and we hanged up .. 5 minutes later someone from whitht jr is calling me i told him i was busy and that they should call me next day at 12pm as instructed by me 5 min ago. Nextday they called me at 7am then at 9am then i felt they are forcing it at me, they called at 12 and i didnt answer coz i was not really in the mood after all .. so they called my wife, and she asked them not to do that, they called her again asking why i dont answer .. it was horrible, i never said no to them i wanted to wait and see if they ever respect my time .. they kept stalkin me for 2 weeks they offered huge discounts from $400 to $300 to $200 to $120 and they kept sayin that my son is very smart and he got a scholorship thats why they give me a discount, i felt there is something suspecious about them eventhough they are legit, but the fact that they instructrd my son all the way for 1 hour without giving him a chance to think made me conclude that they ll just continue doing that and my son will follow the instruction brainlessely. He wont be learning anything! … i dont like to be forced or pushed into somethin so i went to youtube and started researching some other resources and i found here Learn computer science. Change the world. Seriously they have 10 times better excersis and toturial and it starts very simple u can learn it urself while u go through it with ur kid .. its fun game and its free. my advice is to save your money, spend more time with ur children and learn together with them on that site What they are going to learn either in code dot org or in white hatjar is the same, its what is called abstract coding, its not real coding, its coding through playing a game and putting buliding blocks of functions together, kids will learn the basic concepts and the logic behind coding and how to apply loops, create functions and if statments but its building block only, Which brings a very important point i would like to mention for all parents, when u teach ur kids abstract coding it is very hard to convince them to migrate from abstract coding to real coding , which also involve mathmatics most kids would give up, , so parents should be aware of that and introduce simple coding languages such as logo (turtle academy) or html and improve their mathmatical skills along the way

Update (July 16) At the time of posting the below review on April 16th, I had no clue or expectations on how the review would be considered. After 60k views and 200 upvotes, I think it’s time for an update. Why the Review I wrote it for the same reason anyone would write a review. It is for the reader to make an informed decision. My review was received positively as well as negatively. Those who were positive were kind enough to state that my review has helped them make an informed choice and those who gave negative feedback has stated that I’m doing marketing or WhiteHat Jr is sham or I’m not a real person. About Me I’m a Corporate Employee and this post isn’t sponsored or is neither a marketing sham for WhiteHat. The review is an honest opinion on WhiteHat based on the Trail class my daughter attended two months back. Two Months Later I stand by what I have written below. My daughter continues to enjoy using WhiteHat Jr and the classes. In fact she looks forward to attend these sessions. There have been occasions she has found the course tough and in that cases, we have sought the teachers help. Advice for Parents I often read in the comments about the marketing strategy of WhiteHat. I guess it’s fair to say that every organisation has the right to market their product they want to unless they are misleading. My recommendation is to check if your kid is showing interest in the trail class and whether you liked how the format looks. Don’t expect your kid to make any money or your kid to become a coding vizard. Coding takes time and this is the first step. Keep your expectations real. Original Post I’m literally taken aback by some of the strong negative feedback WHJr has received in this platform so far. I may be too early to comment on the feedback as my 8yr old daughter is in the initial stages of her paid classes. Having said so I have to be mindful of not being drawn into giving overtly praise just because I have paid and have to support the organisation. Before I get into the review of other reviews, let me give you an overview of what WHJr is and how it works. I will then get into some of the criticisms given by disappointed parents. What is White Hat Jr They are an Online learning platform that give 1:1 classes to kids.They have 3 different type of courses that you can sign for. One for 1 class which can ignored, other is for 48 classes and the the last one is for 144 classes.The course fee is based on per class. 48 classes courses are more costly than 144 classes.They conduct these classes on their own Coding platform which, so far ,my kid has absolutely loved. How are the classes conducted?You have to book the class in advance based on your preferred time slot. If you want to change the time slot you can do so 24 hrs prior. It makes sense as you need to give teacher advance notice for them to schedule their day. What happens if it’s last min cancellation? I have no clue.How is their platform? My initial impressions are that they are really good. For the initial classes, which my daughter is still in, its completely image based. This means the child doesn’t have to write the code but drag and drop the code that’s already written.This gives an easy entrance into coding world without having to worry about writing textual bases coding. It can be a disadvantage if your child is already into text based coding.The coding classes are more of game based with point system to encourage the kids to attempt. I haven’t found any fault yet and hope I don’t find any in the near future.What’s their USP? I guess it’s the 1:1 on coaching. An undivided attention the teacher is giving to 1 student. For me, that’s a blessing.The classes can be moulded as per the child’s leaning potential.I have also been provided with a Relationship Manager’s number who, apart from the teacher, is a touch point for any challenges or issues. Since I’m at the initial stages, I haven’t used any of these resources. (Update July 16: I have used the resources and they are have been supportive)Do you need a high speed internet? To be honest I don’t have an idea as my internet plan is of high speed. (Update July 16: A teacher from WhiteHat has mentioned in the comment that the minimum speed required is 15Mbps)I have read parents complaining the need for high speed internet. I recommend that you check during the trial class.Is it mechanical teaching as one parent said? I don’t understand what the parent meant by it. I didn’t find anything mechanical. They follow a pattern during the course and ask the student to follow the steps. It’s the same as any school syllabus.What, as parents, we should understand is that whether your kid liked the session or not. Since my daughter loved the trial session, and I liked their course structure, I decided to go ahead with the paid plan.Do you get a certificate for attending the trail class? Yes, you do and it’s funny. There is nothing of value apart from igniting the passion of the student and of the parent.It’s a neat sales trick, that’s all. I don’t see any harm. They are doing business and the only question you need to ask if they are keen on delivering what they promised. (Update July 16: So far, they are delivering)Does teachers have industry experience? I haven’t enquired as my interest is on whether the teacher can teach or not.I’m a 17yr experience professional Sales Trainer and I can vouch for the fact that top sales people can’t train and top sale trainer’s can’t sell. People are good at their respective jobIf a teacher is able to identify the kid’s talent, that’s all what’s required.I have to wait and see if that happens. If yes, I’m happy. If not, I will stop the session and get the pro rata refund.About other claims of improved focus and stuff While WHJr do claim that kids have improved focus and stuff, I think it’s a by-product of their interest in the class.This can happen even without a coding class. If you put your kid to any activity they love, they will give their undue attention. Have them sit in front of a tab and watch an animation movie, they will pay undue attention. Simple.However, ‘coding’ develops logical and analytical skills because at the end, they need to know Maths to solve certain issues. Coding is about solving a challenge.Warning - Coding doesn’t make your kid Einstein. They don’t make them Bill Gates or Mark. For that, they need to learn Business.

In a nutshell White Hat Jr = Ride sharing platform + Social Networking App + Retail Store App albeit under the cover of education. It is a mere sales company that runs on gorilla marketing targeting FOMO social anxiety. COVID helped them to get much attention than possible. After almost 40 classes there is no actual coding, still playing with blocks. My kid lost his excitement on programming. The app implements exactly the ride sharing philosophy. The app announces for the availability of instructor matching the requested timings l, After timings-instructor match making the instructors gets allotted. Riders (Child’s) background is irrelevant. The instructor then ‘drives’ (probably bulldozing is a right term) the student to the ‘destination’ ie., complete the session. No driving is taught. The platform is not responsible for any wreckage. 10 hour per day duties for the instructors. I believe White hat Jr is cashing out on the craze for the reputed institutions than actually sharing what they were taught or learnt. Poor souls who have fascination for IIX, Google, FB, NASA, Polar Expedition,, Ride to Mars etc whatnot for your beloved ones - you are a pretty nice target. Even worse they are annoyingly a marketing mill. Looks like they sold my data to other ‘education services’ without my obvious consent. I keep getting related calls relentlessly, at least half a dozen WhatsApp messages per day ( by the way you won’t be asked for your consent to blast you over WhatsApp). What kind of service that bombards ads with flying balloons, flashy coupons, raffles, Tesla car? Doesn’t sound familiar? My honest suggestion particularly to those who stretch themselves financially hoping for a reasonable outcome for their beloved ones - don’t risk. Go find someone who teaches with a heart full of warm feeling for the education.

TL;DR: WhiteHatJr fools people with buzzwords and mines & profiles every shred of their kids' (and probably parents' too) data. I will use Wayback Machine links for references so as to save the snapshot incase they change the website. I will also use mobile screenshots instead of a desktop so as to make them more readable for mobile users.  Let's start with a cursory look at their homepage.[1]  1:1 online coding classes. Does that mean every child gets personal attention? The teacher's seemingly stock photo there makes me think they want that to imply. *Last 19 Spots Left We all know this strategy, needs no introduction. Also, it seems like their coders, or the program they coded doesn't know the rules of grammar.  Lots of buzzwords sprinkled here and there. Silicon valley, Google, Waymo, and what not. I doubt a kid who doesn't know what is 23² would be able to handle the heavy data and statistics used in machine learning at Waymo offices. Also, more than 3 lakh reviews by students. Earlier they said there was 1:1 teaching. Do they have 3 lakh educators? Lmfao. Okay you might say let's cut some slack since the company is fairly recent. So we can assume they have atleast 10% the number of educators. 30k teachers, is it? Apparently, they have 7k teachers. If every educator made the kid capable for a job involving stuff with driverless cars, they are either very supreme beings who decided to stay underground for years and then suddenly come together to work for this company, or the claim is fake. The homepage consists of more buzzwords (including a claim about 1 million+ students (1M == 10L) being associated. Adds a cherry to the 1:1 claim) and extolling about their teachers. One particular thing I would like to point out is their age and price requirements:  Huh a class 1 student who generally doesn't know trigonometry will code for space missions. Just for a nominal price of ₹1L. I guess all our schools and colleges are soon going to be obsolete. Finally! Thanks, whitehatjr! /s  Before proceeding, let us take a quick look at the detailed curriculum of their ₹99,999 (or I should say ₹1,07,999) plan for grade 1.[2] They don't even use the Indian numbering system, so much for educating India's kids.  Woah! So advanced syllabus! Jokes and sarcasm aside, I don't even need to go into that “syllabus” to point out it's total scam in the name of “AI/ML” (like almost always). Most of it seems like drag and drop stuff branded like AI/ML. Let's cut some slack considering its class 1, let's look at class 10+ curriculum.[3]  BRUH MOMENT. You are paying ONE BLEEPING LAKH RUPEES for this, which is just school education. Why do I say this? Here's why:  Hmm cool, let's look at the juicy things I'm gonna learn for building the next Google! Aatmanirbhar Bharat, here I come!  For teaching AI/ML to you, they will first teach you what are variables, if else conditionals, loops, and functions.Then they will teach you graphs and Pandas “dataframes” and numpy “arrays”. Without any knowledge of what's happening and how their data is actually fed or manipulated!AFTER teaching you numpy and cooldude hackerman data science stuff, they will teach you the basic building blocks, viz., strings, list, tuples, and dictionaries!Then you'll study some basic statistics taught in class 12. Remember, after graphs, plots, Panda dataframes, and numpy!So much bluffing. Similar goes for the tasks on the right.  Some more class 12 statistics and CS stuff. The major bluff here is about “XGBoost”. The arxiv print[4] (submitted on 2016) has the following abstract: Tree boosting is a highly effective and widely used machine learning method. In this paper, we describe a scalable end-to-end tree boosting system called XGBoost, which is used widely by data scientists to achieve state-of-the-art results on many machine learning challenges. We propose a novel sparsity-aware algorithm for sparse data and weighted quantile sketch for approximate tree learning. More importantly, we provide insights on cache access patterns, data compression and sharding to build a scalable tree boosting system. By combining these insights, XGBoost scales beyond billions of examples using far fewer resources than existing systems. And the paper consists of stuff like this:  or  This is not the stuff a 14 year old learns (unless your kid is some math genius like Terence Tao, at that point you would know it's futile to waste money here). Even yours truly does not know it and hence is unable to explain it to you. Finally let's look at the third part. You'd expect some more advanced and juicy stuff.  Oh, so we are back to statistics marketed with buzzwords and captivating tasks. We also see a mention about absolute basic things like matrices and covariance, taught in class 12 and college courses which are not on AI or ML. Whitehatjr doesn't fail to disappoint you more, isn't it?  Before proceeding to the last part, I chanced upon a blog post of theirs. This absolutely shreds any credibility they may have in your mind, if you know stuff about programming.[5] A prior knowledge about programming helps here.  Oh, >programming language of HTML >best use of PHP is interactive pages with WordPress and Drupal >PHP is LITTLE difficult for “small” kids >it is EASY to learn for more mature kids  So according to them Lua is the best introductory language, and Lua code is upon Roblox's default (?) boilerplate (they didn't even use the correct word and terminologies lmao).  Well, it turns out learning PHP and Lua was just scratch. Now the actual beast, Python, has entered into the game! Wow! Also, there is a very kid friendly reference, Python.org, quoted there!  >So the reason Java is popular is because of Minecraft. >Minecraft has its own name among programming languages. >Inb4 Java == Minecraft >Minecraft as a learning tool for Java. >Tfw you realise Minecraft is closed source.  Now, let's see their privacy policy.[6] I'll just quote it here and add emphasis, since a screenshot would be too impractical. We collect information that may be used to identify you or your Child (“Personal Information”) including, but not limited to, (i) name, e-mail ID, photograph, location and other contact information (ii) gender and other demographics (iii) birth date and year of the Child to validate their age.We also collect certain information either when you provide it using the Platform or Services and/or automatically as you or the Child navigate through the Platform (which may include usage details, IP address, device ID and type, your browser type and language, the operating system used by the device, access times, and information collected through cookies, web beacons and other tracking technologies). You agree that we may use such information to do internal research on our Users' demographics to better understand, protect and serve our Users.So they collect all PII of the child, and track the child. But this is nothing, see the next part: We collect information from your user ID associated with any social media account (such as your Facebook and Google account) that users use to sign into the Platform or connect with or use of our Services. When you sign in with your social media account information, or otherwise connect to your social media account with the Platform, you consent to our collection, storage, and use, in accordance with this Privacy Policy, of the information that you make available to us through the social media interface. This includes, without limitation, any information that you have made public through your social media account, information that the social media service shares with us or information that is disclosed during the sign-up and sign-in processes.So any social media you link to them, they have the rights to store and mine every single shred of information on that profile which is public, plus the information you give them access to while signing in. Basically, you are allowing them to collect every data available on your social media sites. If any of the Users allows us to collect information from his or her device phonebook—and you or the Child’s are one of that User’s contacts—we may combine the information we collect from that User’s phonebook with other information we have collected about you. We may also obtain information from other sources and combine that with the information we collect through the Platform.So they are correlating your profile and information with others, which includes using phonebook and mobile numbers. So basically, you're giving them a free pass to profile your children from their digital infancy. And they make it absolutely clear later: You agree that we may use Personal Information about you to improve our marketing and promotional efforts, to analyse site usage, improve the Platform's content and Service offerings, and customize the Platform's content, layout, and Services. These uses improve the Platform and better tailor it to meet your needs, so as to provide you with an efficient, safe and customized experience while using the Platform. So whitehatjr is basically Bluffing around both at the homepage and at the curriculum.Got technical about programming itself wrong. So much for teaching programming.Meanwhile they capture every bit (pun intended) of information about you and your child to profile you and use it for more targetted advertisement and more tracking. Essentially monetising it while your child is profiled since day 1.Your child gets nothing to learn and you lose money on sketchy claims. Thanks for reading! ~ Siddh Raman Pant (सिद्ध रमन पंत)  EDIT 1 (4/10/2020): Here are some videos which will demonstrate the superior quality of education at whitehatjr! https://youtu.be/qbtMCRRSsuc https://youtu.be/E09n3BkrI_I Both have been archived in case they get taken down.[7][8] Footnotes[1] Live Online Coding for Kids | WhiteHat Jr.[2] https://web.archive.org/web/20201001200711/https://cdnwhjr.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/website/curriculumpdf/12-mar-2020/details/BEG.pdf[3] https://web.archive.org/web/20201001201804/https://cdnwhjr.s3.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/website/curriculumpdf/12-mar-2020/details/APT.pdf[4] XGBoost: A Scalable Tree Boosting System[5] The 6 Best Kids Coding Languages | Kids Coding | WhiteHat Jr[6] https://web.archive.org/web/20201001214127/https://code.whitehatjr.com/privacy-policy[7] https://web.archive.org/web/20201004065219/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qbtMCRRSsuc&feature=youtu.be[8] https://web.archive.org/web/20201004065406/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E09n3BkrI_I&feature=youtu.be

We sat for a trial class. The first try, the teacher's headset didn't work and she cut in and out. When we could hear, I noticed two things. 1) the accent of the teacher made it difficult to understand 2) she strictly followed a script while teaching 3) when we explained we couldn't understand, she simply repeated whatever was on her script. Strange. They let us reschedule so we tried again… Next try, no technical difficulties and less accent but like before, the teacher read from a script. She sometimes restated things but made little effort to personalize the session to the student. She was constantly trying to get back to her script. The decision was not to use their service. I wasn't confident the teachers would individualize their sessions so what was the point? I was interested in paying for tutoring, not a script. After that, came a daily bombardment of marketing through every medium they had access to. I had to quickly unsubscribe from text to several different numbers and then finally block the numbers. I also had to block them on WhatsApp. Then email. Then had to tell more than one telesales person to stop calling. That was pretty annoying. They sent lots of childishly manipulative emails before the unsubscribe about how my kid is top rated for a bunch of random stuff that they made up. The over-the-top marketing paired with underhanded manipulation makes me ill at ease. That along with the scripted teaching and the sales pitches from the teachers made me feel not too confident in the service. I get the feeling this is a money making scheme with as many untrained “teachers” as possible with little caring as to the successful learning of the individual student. Not for us.

I actually figured out that it was a scam while the call and thirty minutes after it. I’m actually the one that was on the call, I’m 12 years old and i figured out something was fishy while talking to them. First of all, on Oct 4th, I was a few minutes earlier than expected, I was waiting for it to start. The meeting was supposed to start at 6:00 and I was surprised that she still isn’t there, and i know you’re wondering why did you think there was something fishy there? Well it’s because the program is for a “scholarship” from a great school in canada and they’re supposed to be proper and always on time,and if you’re trying to get students to enroll in your school, you must maintain professional. that’s the first red flag. Second red flag. MY TEACHER WAS INDIAN. No I’m not being racist, it’s just cause indians are known for their scams on the internet and the “scholarship” isn’t even from india IT WAS ON CANADA. If the “scholarship” is for canada then aren’t the teacher,technicians, and creators supposed to be canadian too if that’s the case? But I let it be ;-; Third red flag. The compliments and rewards. I too was kind of fooled by this, if you’re wondering why it’s because children are desperate for compliments any kind of compliment you say they will accept. The compliments were very iffy too, It was like they were trying to get the children to ask and beg their parents to get enrolled in the course. WHEN I WAS ASKED A QUESTION I DIDN’T EVEN ANSWERED CORRECTLY AND THEY GAVE ME A HATS OFF FOR IT???? WTH! I also think she was done with me cause it took me thirty seconds to find something hehehehe. (btw im kind of a dumb kid so yeah) But i let it be again ;——-; Fourth red flag. After the “learning” After “teaching” me she told me to look at a link which showed the “apps” and “chatbots” children made while learning at whitehatjunior she also showed me what I will be learning when I enroll at that course, some of them were “modeling”,”creating bigger apps” and etc. She showed these things so that the children and parents will believe it which I gotta say is pretty clever ;))) Here I was actually kinda more sketchy about it. Fifth red flag. The DM’s After the “class” they sent some things to my mother’s google account, some of these said “Wow, your child is as smart as Einstein” BS which is not true (believe me) And they also sent some pricey “Discounts” for the scholarship. When my mom showed these things to me I told her that It’s probably a scam(And here I was immedietely sure it was) and We should not enroll there. A few days later until today I wondered and wondered whether it was a scam or not so I just searched the internet. Also, during my meeting my teacher had trouble with her internet so I had to wait for a little while again, AND THEN, the technicians came in the call and told me my teacher had problems, “why?, why are you so suspicious of them their just technicians” If that’s what you are asking it was because they were m e n, and sometimes men are untrustworthy, also i think they just did that to see how I’m doing in the call idk it’s probably just me. Parents side note: Never pay for sites that may seem sketchy to you, always remember to research more about that site and be careful. And yes I am a child :DDD

Literally, the best place to learn coding for your children is YouTube. WhiteHat Jr is just a joke. I went on the website just by reading on an article, a coding platform for kids, I mean the what? And this is how the site looks.  Let me show you how hard it is to be a silicon valley engineer. This is William Lin, one of the favorite channels of whom I watch to keep my coding gist to then top and learn new concepts. He is also a class leading competitive coder, one of the best I have seen.  If you have any issues regarding understanding, why I am comparing them together, just look at the First screenshot and then go to his channel and give a watch to his videos. If you are a parent yourself, you should see his videos and learn, how hard is it to code in the competitive ground. Yes, app development is a different thing but whiteHat.Jr claims to be making your child a silicon valley winner and I don't see him/her getting the S of silicon valley unless your child is a competitive coder. App development is way below or way after than that. Now just ask yourself a question? Is whiteHat.Jr a proper coding platform for your children? Or do you even know what sort of basics it requires to even understand the ground of coding. The concept of coding isnt just writing code that will do a simple task. It's a mere engineering term if you don't know. Why? Why bring Engineering in coding? When you write a code, you usually define a task to the computer which it will understand from the code and compile it to produce a machine language program which the processor in the computer will understand and produce the required output. So what you actually do here? You write a code indirectly for the processor.You have to mention the steps and the sequence to process.You have to give the data.You have to specify the location for the data.You have to define the right syntax which I think isn't that hard if you know the language.You have to understand the basics of general programming.You have to build logic which is the most important part.You have to understand sequential analysis of coding to generate a working simulation of the problem.You have to understand the concept of output and it's manipulation process to generate a pattern if required.And most importantly, you have to know how a computer processes these in the most basic way(else you are stuck with conditions).See all these issues related to coding? This will come up on any child's mind and the necessary answers are required to given to them. This is relevant whether you write a hello world program or a linked list with self evolving and optimisation feature. Coding is now taken a very common concept which everybody can learn. But the reality is very less know. Out of millions students, only a very negligible percentage of 0.01% get to understand the main motive of coding. So what to do for your child to teach him coding ? There is always a basic for everything. You cannot learn mathematics not unless you deal your way wit numbers and Arithmetic. Similarly for coding, your child needs to have a brief understanding of logic, computers and very concept of bits. The best for book for your child to start learning coding is to grab this book.  The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software by Charles Petzold. In this book, you get to know about computers right from the basics of bits, how they are used in a variety of fields and how it advanced to the computer technology with architecture language. The entire book is written like a story book and your child won't even find it boring, just that not many pictures are present though. But the entire book is very interesting, for almost any one who is starting to learn coding, whether he or she is a 6–7 year old or a engineering student. I am not against the platform, but they are actually missing out a bit of context that should be available to the young minds. Coding is a complex subject, that basically belongs to Computer Science. Only a tiny part of it is taught in Usual Primary Schools for students to have a liking towards programming. I am saying from the perspective of experience, as in my days of high school, I was not even able to write a single line of code on my own, as the concept just went right through my head. But when I joined college, I got myself acquainted with base programming easily, since I found out missing concepts on my understanding. I started from very basic and got the actual idea of writing code that made sense to the computers. I have written a very basic and simple concept based programming book that actually contains all the basics to learn any coding language fast, just with the right basics using simple algorithms and Flowcharts(which is a very basic concept introduced for 10–11 year olds). It has lots of exercises for your child to easily understand and learn easily. You can download it from here for free! Conceptual Programming_AS_2020_done!.pdf

I weird I am writing this answer, because I thought it was a joke a few months ago, but I only realised the seriousness of this company a few days ago. So let me start a few months ago, as usual I was searching around Quora and reading a lot of stuff, after getting bored, I was watching some food review shows and ended up getting an ad from white hat jr. So basically it was some 10-13 year old girl called sakshi or arushi writing some application and starting a company. There was a was fishy feeling from that weird ad, so my inquisitive nature started to push me to look at some reviews and I ended up searching Quora. Almost all the reviews were written in a positive manner, I really started to doubt whether they were actually written by customers or employees. That's weird!! Like it's a rule to have atleast one negative review even if you have something that could save the world. How could some product or service not get a single bad review? So after some detailed researching I realised these guys at whitehat jr, did not even teach people how to code, they used some sort of block.ly based scripted webapp to design their so called 'apps'. All those media articles that they tell you about often are authors who get a commission to write their stories. Yes such people do exist, even those people at Forbes, often they use it as a Marketing space to promote products. So forget the flash stories of going to silicon valley and meeting Elon Musk in at spaceX or becoming the CEO of Google (wait if people who do their PhD's in the US cant get a job in the US, where will chintu get a job with a useless certificate) those certificates almost have no value, simply because those kids haven't programmed in an actuall language. Imagine If a guy in a suite asks you a $100 to teach a kid to ride a toy car, and you say some confusing buzz words and car jargon. Then once you have done that you get a certificate with a big logo and a name, do you expect the DMV to give your kid a drivers license?? (I know the analogy is horrible but hear me out) In their curriculum PDF for the APT course , they haven't taught the kids python, but they move on to k-means algorithm, better than that neural networks algorithms. Wait a minute, kid if your 7 years old you probably don't know what 7 multiplied by 7 is, then how the heck do you do differential calculus? (Anyway how did you get past the LMS learning rule and the General Delta rule? Heck how would the average angry bird playing 7 year old know what a logarithm is?) The thing is, if you find whatever buzz words extremely confusing and can't understand what that meant after an extensive Google search, that's just the tip of the ice berg, because you could not have run a simple Adaline with out understanding the theory in that. Even PhD researchers have to scratch their heads when it comes to ML and AI, I know many companies have to hire mathematicians just to get their algorithms to be written down on the white board. Heck, how would chintu get through this ? ( If chintu could write a neural network himself at 7, he would never be paying for white hat jr.) So essentially this whole concept spreads from the Indian IIT rat race. Making a 6th standard boy to 12th standard maths and memorize sums. The problem is coding is not about what you know or can know , it's more about questioning and rethinking what you know. (It's not abt making or breaking stuff). If this pattern is repeated, it just enforces that same mediocrity in computer programming. Most of these kids who finish their white hat jr courses will probably not be able to code in actual python or javascript. Heck these people think java become famous because people play minecraft, you think linux (sorry it's GNU/Linux) became famous cause penguins were starting to die in antartica?? So now we come to a few weeks before from today. At that point I got very annoyed by the unrealistic white hat jr ads and adverts that kept popping up in my window. But ironically white hat jr, was doing one good thing, it was actually making people watch more free online content that actually had some quality time in them or a good read. It made kids do more, atleast try to learn a useful skill. But chintu can never get a job at Google for 150 crores per annum (edit: even Google VP makes salary of $710,000 per annum which is about 5.2 crore ruppees.), nor can he even get a simple technician job with any of those certificates as they don't have value. In simple language it is a plain legal scam, do not join it. Comments are welcome!! Thanks for the upvotes!!

This question frequents my feed. So I wanted to share my experience. I am not a parent but was an applicant for the post of coding instructor. I am a developer and will answer from this perspective. I had lost my job and was desperate few months back to find any thing and everything. Though I am very much patient in my search now. I shared my interview experience on Medium[1] That's when I introspected. All they want is a 45 min scripted class. You need to mug up the script step by step. Line by line. The first thing as a teacher is you should have no mother tongue influence. Okay, mother tongue influence makes me a bad teacher? Maybe. There is a long pitch which you have to deliver at the end of each demo class. Their focus was more on the pitch than on my code. Even in industry one doesn't mug up code. One has to write logic to solve the problem. There is no teacher sitting at the other side of the screen to help you.  This post was shared by one of the parents.  Their advertisements to lure teachers claims to meet the financial goals of the teacher. There are no words like passion or interest in coding. How will a child learn to code when a teacher shows them how to think at every line. Typing on a screen is not coding. An easy work from home is amazing. But not at the costs of young minds. Now I think I was saved. In this era of joblessness any source of income is a boon. What if I would have been hired as the coding instructor? I would be still working for them. But in future if I want to join the industry again this experience of coding scripted games would take me nowhere. Image Source: LinkedIn Footnotes[1] http://“WhiteHat Jr Interview experience. Teacher recruitment reviews and process” by Jagruti Tiwari https://link.medium.com/9Rj3rxo0qab

As a computer engineer, it is really humiliating when some website comes up with an advertisement stating that some 6 year old Chintu can also learn coding and make their own apps. This kind of things put us in an inferiority complex and it makes us wonder what did we accomplish in engineering college? I had been learning programming since Class 9 in Java. Over the years I have learnt many more programming languages and built academic projects with teams of 2–6 people, personal mini-projects and I know how much amount of knowledge and team effort is required to do all these. And then suddenly one kid whose age is less than the number of years I have been coding comes up and tells they can learn coding from some website and built an app of their own. And apparently, angel investors will be fighting against each other in front of your house to invest in your product.  Hence I decided to check how authentic this website truly is and the best way to test it would be to attend their class. But I know I cannot attend their class since I don't look like a school kid anymore. But my brother recently passed out from school and I made him my guinea pig. I registered him as a Class 12 student and he did the rest. He created an account on the website and was looking to book a trial class. Now, do note that they advertise their free trial classes on the advertisement. But in reality, you cannot book that trial class. It shows that all the trial classes are booked and one had to buy the paid classes subscription.  A very nice marketing gimmick to attract students to their platform and then redirect them to the paid courses. But I decided to explore their courses and take a look at what they offered. The first one that caught my attention was on Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning.  Where on Earth would you find a course priced at Rs 1 lakh? Can you imagine paying one lakh rupees for an online course? I mean, there are so many free platforms like Udemy, Coursera, Khan Academy and of course, YouTube where you get far better content. And yet they mention this as their 'most popular' course, tricking the parents to buy this one! There was another course on the landing page next to this for Python.  Eight classes cost Rs 6,000. What would they even teach you in eight classed? You'll learn absolutely nothing in 8 days. It takes a longer time get a grasp on a new programming language, specially if you are a school kid. I learnt Python during my second year of engineering from various online platforms but free of cost. And it definitely took me more than eight days. Truth be told, eight classes will cover nothing at all.  This proves that Whitehat Jr is on a mission to brainwash the young kids and deceive the parents into enrolling their children into these overpriced courses. The teachers at Whitehar are not even qualified. They recruit teachers without any coding experience as it is evident from their job posting.  Apparently no coding knowledge is required to teach coding. You can very well understand what your child will learn from them. They train their teachers on sales and marketing, how to convince the parents in buying their product rather than actually teaching them. This is the exact same thing, their parent company BYJU's does and Whitehat Jr is no different.

I have been observing a lot of these WhiteHat Jr. ads between IPL Matches. So I decided to see what it was all about. I checked a couple of their advertisements and this is what I concluded: Computer Science is a lot more than coding. The way WhiteHat Jr. has approached the subject of Computer Science is the typical Indian way of making kids memorize code blocks and syntaxes, but coding is more than just programming some pre-built app in a 45 minute class. It has got a lot to do with solving real world problems. They claim they teach SpaceTech and AI, Machine Learning to kids. I honestly don’t think a kid would have the aptitude in mathematics to learn these kinds of things:  And if you think this is just some random image from the internet that I have pasted here to scare you, you are mistaken. WhiteHat Jr. boldly claims in their syllabus that they would teach regression, advanced statistics with Machine Learning to a kid in 10th grade. Seriously?? Even university level mathematics would not suffice to learn such concepts, in my opinion. And the claims about 13 year old kids and 9 year old kids getting jobs at Google are false. How can a 9 year old get a job at a FANG company if there are bucket loads of adult applications being rejected?? Google is hyper selective about whom they hire, and they want top talent. A mere WhiteHat Jr. certification simply cannot earn you a multi-million dollar job, it is the reality. India’s top quality engineers are from the IIT’s, right? Now, the way media hypes up the 1.5 cr packages itself is fake, because only about 5–10 engineers across all IIT’s get such high paying jobs abroad. Then how can a 9 year old who hasn’t even finished primary education learn AI and get such high salaries. It is nothing but a mere marketing tactic. They are playing with your mind by making it look like coding is a very advanced thing. It isn’t. And there is a lot, lot more to computer science. A mere coder who can only copy paste and drag and drop code has a 0% chance of being hired by Google. There are much better sources on the internet. You only have to find them. And 90% of them are free. They also have the same syllabus. Don’t waste your money on the very definition of a piece of crap- WhiteHat Jr. All the best!

I will answer it with one of my twitter posts.  White hat junior only teaches you to drag and drop. It makes children use specific templates to make an app. But coding is much more than that. When everyone says that coding is important, it doesn't mean that you should know how to make an app. Learning coding moulds your brain into thinking in a different way which helps in many life challenges. For example, there is a concept called recursion. Recursion is the process of defining a problem (or the solution to a problem) in terms of (a simpler version of) itself. When you solve a problem, initially you think about what you have to do first and then the next step and so on. But in recursion you first have to think where do you have to stop or the base case as we call it meaning where you have to end. For example, if you have to find the factorial of a number n, (factorial of a number is the product of all the positive integers less than the number) you would multiply n by factorial of n-1 but you would have to set the base case as when it reaches 2 or 1 (because any number multiplied by 1 is the number itself) it has to stop. Thus you are thinking about the end first. This is just one example. So I would recommend not teaching your children coding through platforms whose primary motive is to teach children their drag and drop feature in the name of building apps. Instead start with teaching them a programming language and making small programs from them. I would recommend from youtube for a start and then professional courses.

White Hat Jr. is a user-friendly and intuitive educational technology organization founded by Karan Bajaj in 2018. WhiteHat Jr. takes a straight-forward approach, teaching real text-based code in a manner that even 9-year-olds can understand and apply their knowledge to build apps. Here is the story of a White Hat Jr. student, 9-year-old Mae Mae from Shillong, who created the Anti-Bullying app for kids to report bullies anonymously and alert parents, teachers, and friends about them. Mae Mae and her sister had faced bullying at school, and she wanted to put an end to this. While learning to code on the WhiteHat Jr. platform, Mae Mae thought of using her knowledge to create an app to help other kids cope with bullies. Once logged in, the child can anonymously share details of the incident including the name of the bully and give a detailed explanation of how they were mistreated. This will notify their parents and teachers and encourage them to take necessary disciplinary action to nip the problem in the bud.

So WhitehatJr approached me to recruit for their teaching position. They were like I don’t need to go to office, I can work from home. I just need to work specific hours per day. Sounded good. Then they mentioned coding knowledge is not required to teach coding to children. I was like WTF just I read? Yes even my friend pursuing m.tech from IIT Madras also got same thing. He is pursuing m.tech in CS but it was mentioned no coding knowledge required to teach coding to children. So how exactly are you going to teach coding to children without knowing how to code? That meant, they would give us pre-designed course that we would have to just read it out to children. Is that teaching coding! Man even we had better History classes in school than this. They were not going to pay us for using our laptop for their work nor going to pay for our own internet which we were going to use for their official work. So the overall pay was shitty. Atleast companies like Chegg’s expert pay us much more per hour. So now you decide. -S.Sarkar

An online education platform stands for delivery of educational content to students. The platform, unlike a textbook is an interactive space where students can engage with the content. And therefore, these platforms are in huge demand in schools and universities across the globe. Because every institution wishes their students to understand the concepts and its implications in the real world.  This high demand has ended in the production and availability of many such online education platforms in the market, putting educational institutions in a dilemma. How do they decide which platform functions best for their students? Every vendor claims to have the best learning platform which is best for students and teachers. They all have many features are more or less similar to one another. 1. Fluid-to-use interface First of all, we require an interface that is easy to use. The icons and text should be visible and legible. Teachers and students must be able to navigate through the app easily. A good online platform should have the following aspects: Global Compatibility There are many online learning platforms with a varying number of users. Scaling of teaching effectiveness Online portals that allow teachers to build their online academies and get actionable information about their courses, classes, and content delivery. Such handy features enable teachers to get insights into students’ activities through informative reports which cover information, such as content consumed by each student, live classes attended, and the percentage of the course completed to keep a tab on the number of dropouts. Teachers can use this data to refine their course content or courseware design, improve their teaching approach or methodology, and do a lot more to increase student engagement to improve learning outcomes. Content Protection One of the ways to claim content ownership is by controlling the dissemination and access of content so that it’s accessible to only the assigned students. Server security, encryption types and other such technologies are used to protect your data safe on online platforms, so before deciding on which one you are going with, make sure to get a good understanding of who gets to access your data and how they get to do it.  Versatility The versatility of the software or platform decides the type of online learning activities that you can do. You need to take into consideration the level and type of interaction that you normally have with your teachers and choose the platform accordingly. Mobile methodologies As pedagogy and learning needs change, learning tools change. With the online education landscape changing rapidly, teachers and students are adapting to novel technologies. As more and more people join the online community due to ease of use, scalability, flexibility, affordability and choosing the right platform or software continues to remain a crucial factor in the success of your teaching, training or business.
